skill.name: feedback-mastery
skill.description: Navigate difficult conversations and deliver constructive feedback using structured frameworks. Covers the Preparation-Delivery-Follow-up model and Situation-Behavior-Impact (SBI) feedback technique.
skill.summary: Master difficult workplace conversations with proven frameworks for giving and receiving feedback effectively.
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: All 49 static analysis findings have been evaluated and determined to be false positives. The skill contains only documentation about workplace communication frameworks. The 'external_commands' detections were markdown code blocks (triple backticks), 'weak cryptographic algorithm' flags were pattern mismatches on natural language, and 'system reconnaissance' flags were phrases like 'understand what is happening' in feedback contexts. No executable code, network calls, or security risks present.

content.value_statement: Giving feedback is hard. This skill gives you proven frameworks like SBI (Situation-Behavior-Impact) and the Preparation-Delivery-Follow-up model to navigate difficult conversations with confidence and achieve better outcomes.
actual_capabilities: Structure feedback using the SBI (Situation-Behavior-Impact) model for clarity and impact
Prepare for difficult conversations using the three-phase framework
Generate opening lines and responses for common workplace scenarios
Reframe accusatory statements into constructive dialogue
Handle defensiveness, deflection, and emotional reactions during feedback
Create follow-up plans and documentation for accountability
limitations: Does not replace HR or legal guidance for serious disciplinary issues
Requires user to provide specific context and examples from their situation
Cannot observe actual conversations or provide real-time coaching
Frameworks work best when adapted to individual communication styles

use_cases.title: Address Performance Issues
use_cases.description: A manager needs to discuss missed deadlines or quality concerns with a team member. The skill provides SBI-structured feedback examples and scripts for opening the conversation constructively.

use_cases.title: Resolve Team Conflicts
use_cases.description: Two engineers disagree on technical approach and tension is affecting the team. The skill offers facilitation scripts and frameworks for finding common ground.

use_cases.title: Push Back on Unrealistic Deadlines
use_cases.description: Leadership wants a feature delivered in half the estimated time. The skill provides data-driven approaches for resetting expectations and presenting trade-offs professionally.

prompt_templates.title: Prepare for a Difficult Conversation
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to give feedback to [name] about [specific issue]. Help me prepare using the Preparation-Delivery-Follow-up framework. What should I consider before the conversation?
prompt_templates.scenario: Initial preparation before addressing a workplace issue

prompt_templates.title: Structure Feedback with SBI
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me structure feedback using the SBI model. The situation is: [describe when/where]. The behavior I observed: [describe what they did]. The impact was: [describe effect]. How can I phrase this effectively?
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating specific, objective feedback that reduces defensiveness

prompt_templates.title: Handle a Defensive Reaction
prompt_templates.prompt: I am giving feedback and the person is getting defensive. They said: [their response]. How should I respond to keep the conversation productive?
prompt_templates.scenario: Managing common reactions during difficult conversations

prompt_templates.title: Facilitate Conflict Resolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Two team members [names] are in conflict about [topic]. It is affecting the team. Walk me through how to facilitate a resolution meeting using the frameworks.
prompt_templates.scenario: Mediating between colleagues with differing perspectives

output_examples.input: Help me give feedback to my developer about missing deadlines
output_examples.output:
Here is an SBI-structured approach for your conversation:

**Preparation:**
- Gather specific examples (which deadlines, by how much)
- Define your goal: behavior change, not punishment
- Check your emotional state before the conversation

**Sample Delivery:**

'Situation: In the last two sprints, the API work was due Wednesday and delivered Friday.

Behavior: The delivery came without advance communication about the delay.

Impact: This blocked the frontend team for two days and caused tension between teams.

I want to understand what is happening and how I can support you. What has been making these deadlines difficult to hit?'

**Follow-up:**
Document agreed actions and check in next week to see if the pattern changes.

output_examples.input: How do I start a conversation about code quality issues?
output_examples.output:
Here are effective opening lines from the difficult conversation scripts:

**Option 1 - Direct but supportive:**
'I want to discuss some patterns I have noticed in recent work. I know you are capable of great work, so I am curious what has been different lately.'

**Option 2 - Collaborative:**
'I have noticed the last few PRs have had more issues than usual. I want to understand what is going on and how we can get back to our usual quality.'

**Option 3 - Process-focused:**
'Let us talk about our testing process. I have seen a few bugs slip through recently and want to understand if something in our setup is making it harder to catch them.'

Avoid starting with 'You always...' or 'Your code has bugs.' Focus on observations and curiosity, not blame.

best_practices: Prepare before the conversation: gather specific examples, define your goal, and check your emotional state
Use facts and observable behaviors rather than interpretations or generalizations like 'always' and 'never'
Focus on impact to the team or project rather than personal feelings or character judgments
Always follow up with written documentation of agreed actions and schedule check-in dates
anti_patterns: Starting with blame or accusations: 'You always miss deadlines' creates defensiveness instead of solutions
Giving feedback when emotionally charged: high emotional intensity reduces your cognitive processing and effectiveness
Skipping the follow-up: without documentation and check-ins, agreements fade and problems recur

faq.question: What is the SBI feedback model?
faq.answer: SBI stands for Situation-Behavior-Impact. It is a structured approach to giving feedback: describe the specific Situation (when and where), the observable Behavior (what they did), and the Impact (effect on team or project). This framework makes feedback specific, objective, and actionable while reducing defensiveness.

faq.question: When should I use this skill?
faq.answer: Use this skill when preparing for difficult conversations, giving constructive feedback, addressing performance issues, navigating conflicts, managing expectations with stakeholders, or receiving feedback yourself. It is designed for workplace communication challenges.

faq.question: How do I handle someone who gets defensive?
faq.answer: Stay curious and acknowledge their perspective. Use phrases like 'I want to understand. Can you walk me through what happened from your perspective?' or 'I believe you had good intentions. Let us talk about the impact regardless of intent.' The skill includes specific response scripts for defensiveness, deflection, emotion, and denial.

faq.question: Can this skill help with positive feedback too?
faq.answer: Yes. The SBI model works excellently for positive recognition. Specific praise like 'During Tuesday's code review (Situation), you caught the edge case that would have caused data loss (Behavior), which prevented a costly production bug (Impact)' is more meaningful than generic 'good job' comments.

faq.question: What if the person denies the behavior happened?
faq.answer: Focus on specifics. Respond with 'I want to make sure we are talking about the same situation. [Describe specific instance with details]. Does that match your recollection?' Having concrete examples with dates, times, or PR numbers makes the feedback harder to dismiss.

faq.question: How do I give feedback to my manager or someone senior to me?
faq.answer: The same frameworks apply. Focus on impact to the project or team rather than personal preferences. Use phrases like 'I want to make sure we deliver something great, and I have some concerns about...' or 'Can we clarify expectations on...?' The skill includes scripts for pushing back on unrealistic deadlines and managing up.
